channel.title: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD)
channel.description: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD) generated by script

item.title: Why does the Taliban remain a point of influence in Bangladesh?
item.description: Afghanistan’s extreme form of Islam has seeped into subtle spaces – and risks Dhaka’s reputation as a global player.

item.title: London calling, political patronage, and the diplomatic curtain
item.description: The Foreign minister’s pledge to prioritise diplomats over politicians hasn’t extended to breaking one posting tradition.

item.title: When women win: India’s cricket revolution
item.description: India’s World Cup victory shows that investing in women’s sport delivers results beyond the boundary, with lessons across the region.

item.title: Mexico has become a less deadly place under Claudia Sheinbaum
item.description: There is still an enormous amount to do in a country deeply in hock to gangsters

item.title: Sharaa’s White House Visit Marks a Reshaping of the Regional Order
item.description: Trump is courting the jihadi-turned-statesman to secure a new ally in the Middle East.

item.title: Trump Courts Sharaa to Secure a New Middle East Ally
item.description: The U.S. and Syrian presidents discussed lifting U.S. sanctions and fighting the Islamic State.

item.title: Why Extreme Weather Hits Southeast Asia So Hard
item.description: The Philippines has been battered by back-to-back typhoons.

item.title: Latin America’s Disjointed Reaction to Trump’s Drug Boat War
item.description: The region is facing historic levels of fragmentation, one expert said.

item.title: Tracking Conflict in the Asia-Pacific: October 2025 Update
item.description: In October, TTP attacks led to cross-border clashes between Pakistan and Afghanistan, Chinese and Philippine vessels faced off in the South China Sea, and the Ta’ang Army in Myanmar agreed to a ceasefire.

item.title: Violence Is the Heart of Brazilian Politics
item.description: An extraordinarily deadly police raid in Rio was anything but an aberration.

item.title: Decoding the Myths: Understanding Hindutva and Hindu Organizations in America
item.description: HSS USA responds to a recent article in The Diplomat.

item.title: Recessions have become ultra-rare. That is storing up trouble
item.description: Continuous growth can make economies fat and slow

item.title: The State of US Asia Policy in the Trump Era, With Special Guest Jim Sciutto
item.description: Reflecting on the U.S. president’s recent Asia trip, how American partners view Trump’s nontraditional diplomatic style, and what (in Asia) keeps Jim up at night.

item.title: How HR took over the world
item.description: The profession has rocketed in size and stature. Will AI shrink it?

item.title: Trump Deals a Blow to Bosnia
item.description: Lifting sanctions on Milorad Dodik is a win for Putin and instability at Europe’s expense.

item.title: Will Israel Wreck the U.S.-Syria Romance?
item.description: By embracing Sharaa, Trump hopes to bring Syria into the U.S. order.

item.title: A C5+1 or 5 C1+1s: The New Math of US Central Asia Policy
item.description: The focus of the C5+1 has narrowed to the economic realm, yielding big deals and sidelining big challenges.

item.title: Millennial Leaders Won the Dutch Elections
item.description: A quiet generational shift is transforming politics.

item.title: Europe Must Close the Space Gap
item.description: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine showed Europeans that they cannot take their security for granted or rely on others for critical functions. Yet the European Union is doing exactly that by allowing itself to fall behind in the new space race.

item.title: Mongolia Badly Needs Education Reform
item.description: A recent teachers’ strike put wages and education inequality at the forefront of public debate.

item.title: Why COP30 may disappoint – again
item.description: Ten years after Paris, climate talks are bogged down by insufficient action, unfinished business, and declining global trust.

item.title: In Putin’s Russia, Even Lawyers Aren’t Safe
item.description: Human rights defenders worry that the line between them and the people they represent is beginning to blur.

item.title: COP30 Must Do Good, Not Just Avoid Harm
item.description: As the host of this year's UN Climate Change Conference, Brazil seeks to make COP30 the “COP of implementation.” Translating commitments into robust action should include providing indigenous peoples with direct access to predictable and sustainable finance, and treating them as equal partners, rather than as beneficiaries.

item.title: The Future of International Aid
item.description: Even without US funding cuts, there would be a need for fresh thinking about how the aid sector works. Financial resources and other programs are not being delivered as efficiently as they could be to do the greatest good for the greatest number of people who are most in need.

item.title: A new project aims to predict how quickly AI will progress
item.description: Superforecasters weigh in on the subject

item.title: The Gyeongju Summit Was a Turning Point for APEC
item.description: The 2025 summit reflected a shift in APEC’s agenda, from U.S.-led liberalization to the rise of AI and East Asian leadership.

item.title: North Korea Test-Fires SRBM as It Denounces South Korea-US Exercises
item.description: The South Korean military said North Korea fired a short-range ballistic missile toward its east coast on Friday.

item.title: Will AI Democratize Access to Equity Financing?
item.description: A century of credit-driven growth has left most economies dependent on banks that fund only the safest bets. By lowering the costs of disclosure, due diligence, and compliance, AI could open equity markets to the smaller, riskier firms that drive innovation and job creation, unlocking a new engine of sustainable growth.

item.title: With Approval Soaring, How Ambitious Can Japan’s New Prime Minister Be?
item.description: Since taking office, Takaichi has shown a willingness to moderate on many issues – with the marked exception of national security policy.

item.title: Why Emerging Economies Are Embracing AI
item.description: Surveys show that emerging economies’ populations are not only well aware of the opportunities AI creates, but also more optimistic about the technology than advanced-economy populations. They might not lead the way in building AI models, but they can use the technology to advance their economic- and social-development goals.

item.title: Mamdani’s Big Bet
item.description: The United States is transforming from a two-party political system into one comprising establishment Republicans, establishment Democrats, alt-right populists, and democratic socialists. In confronting all those who will try to derail him, New York’s mayor-elect will need to keep this big picture in mind.

item.title: Restoring ASEAN’s Collective Negotiating Function
item.description: Bring back ASEAN centrality with a Collective Negotiation Clause.

item.title: Sri Lanka’s Budget Tightens Taxes, Trims Discretion, and Seeks Space for China-India-IMF Balancing
item.description: The next 12 to 18 months, when the political and social costs of broader taxation and administrative centralization will become most visible, are crucial.

item.title: A new model for forest finance or just more debt?
item.description: The Tropical Forests Forever Facility promises billions for conservation but ties conservation funding to the debt burdens already crushing developing economies.

item.title: Closing the Asia-Pacific’s Precision Therapy Access Gap
item.description: Personalized cancer treatments have the potential to transform and extend the life of millions, but the region's healthcare systems are yet to capitalize on the technology.

item.title: Sharaa’s Democratic Test
item.description: The Syrian president, who visits the White House today, just oversaw his first election.

item.title: China Is Already Pulling Ahead on the Next Energy Supply Chain
item.description: Low-emission hydrogen is quickly becoming the latest frontier for geoeconomic competition.

item.title: Why Does the U.S. Set Presidential Term Limits?
item.description: The 22nd Amendment was nothing but an act of vengeance against Roosevelt, Reagan believed.

item.title: America’s Self-Defeating China Strategy
item.description: A policy that confuses strength and weakness.

item.title: How Netanyahu Survives
item.description: Divide and conquer in Gaza and at home.

item.title: Thai Police Issue Arrest Warrant for Cambodian Tycoon Ly Yong Phat
item.description: The 67-year-old senator, a long-time ally of Cambodia's ruling Hun family, has been accused of laundering money generated by cyber-scam centers.

item.title: Australia becomes a risk-taking ally
item.description: AUKUS represents an Australian switch from a practice of risk avoidance to one of eager acceptance.
